entry.title: Accelerate Every Stage of Your SAP Transformation with Enterprise Automation from UiPath and SAP
entry.content:
SAP customers are under pressure to move faster—modernize core systems, accelerate your S/4HANA journey, adopt AI, and do it all while maintaining stability across your operations. That’s why SAP has made enterprise automation a strategic priority across SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

At the center of this strategy is SAP’s Solution Extension partnership with UiPath, the recognized leader in both Robotic Process Automation (RPA) and Intelligent Document Processing (IDP).

By embedding UiPath’s market-leading automation technology directly into SAP Build, SAP delivers a natively integrated solution that empowers you to:

  • Automate across your entire IT landscape, including SAP and non-SAP systems
  • Extend your ERP with automation instead of custom code, maintaining a clean core before, during, and after migration
  • Accelerate your S/4HANA migration by using automation at every phase
  • Include any document in your workflows using enterprise-grade IDP
  • Scale automation securely with built-in governance and native BTP integration

With the UiPath and SAP joint solution, you gain a powerful foundation for end-to-end automation—no matter how complex your systems or processes. From business processes that cut across SAP and non-SAP systems alike—connecting data, decisions, and actions across ERPs, CRMs, emails, documents, and more—UiPath and SAP let you level up to a holistic approach to automation that drives transformational outcomes and AI readiness.

This new eBook from ASUG and UiPath explores how automation helps SAP customers move faster, stay flexible, and prepare for the future with confidence.

In this eBook, you’ll learn:

  • How automation supports every stage of your SAP transformation—from ECC to S/4HANA and beyond
  • How SAP Build and UiPath work together on BTP to reduce complexity, increase agility, and deliver long-term value
  • Why automation is essential for maintaining a clean core, enabling composable architecture, and scaling AI across your business

💡See how SAP is putting automation to work
If you're driving SAP transformation, this eBook shows how SAP and UiPath can help you automate smarter, faster, and more securely—at scale.

👉Read the eBook

Planning an S/4HANA migration? Join UiPath’s resident SAP expert @mark_darbyshire on June 4th to learn in depth how to leverage automation in every phase of S/4HANA migration—eliminating errors, improving data quality, minimizing manual work, speeding up go-live, and addressing clean core.

👉Register for ASUG webcast

entry.title: Mastering SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations , Part 2
entry.content:
In our previous blog post, "Mastering Complex Approvals: A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations," my colleague & SAP Mentor @mohit_bansal3  tackled a common but challenging business requirement: the "all-or-nothing" approval process.

Part 1 - Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations

Part 2 : Current Blog : Demonstration with Complete end to end testing 

We explored how SAP Build Process Automation, leveraging features like Wait Steps with API Triggering and workflow context updates via API, can handle scenarios where multiple approvals are needed simultaneously, and a single rejection stops the entire workflow.

We walked through a procurement example where both Department Managers and the Finance Department had to unanimously approve a request before it could proceed.

Now, in this second blog, we will demonstrate the step-by-step testing process for the solution we developed. This will allow you to understand the entire development flow more deeply, from concept to validation. Let's dive into the testing for the previous blog's implementation!

Handling Approval Outcomes: Positive and Negative Scenarios

The "All-or-Nothing" Positive Scenario : Lets Start the complete Testing Process

Let's first explore the "positive scenario," where every approver gives their stamp of approval. In this ideal outcome, once all required approvals are secured, the main workflow successfully completes its designated task. This seamless progression is the goal of our "All-or-Nothing" design, ensuring that every necessary check is performed before finalization.

Approval Process Triggering
As you know from our previous blog, for demonstration purposes, we created a simple form within SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA). 

 

Main process upon submission of request: Context and log  

You'll notice two approvers listed, which will initiate two parallel workflows. We covered the specifics of these parallel workflows in a previous blog post. The determination of these approvers can come from a decision table or your own custom logic.

The key takeaway here is that we've dynamically fetched two approvers, demonstrating the adaptable nature of this step.  it can handle any number of approvers.

 

 

Dynamically Triggering Secondary Workflows

We're now kicking off secondary workflows dynamically, and the number of these workflows depends entirely on the number of approvers.

For our current scenario, since we have two approvers, this process will trigger two parallel secondary workflows.

Each of these workflows will then send an individual approval request directly to each approver's My Inbox.

Dynamically Secondary Workflow Triggered via API

My Inbox View
Here's a quick look at My Inbox. For this demonstration, we've assigned the same approver.

That's why you see two work items in this approver's inbox. In a real-world scenario, these would be two separate workflow approval items, each in the respective approver's inbox.

Crucially, the main workflow won't complete until both approvals are in.

 

Workflow Progress After First Approval
The screenshot below shows the workflow log after the first approver has taken action. As you can see, the workflow isn't complete yet; it's waiting for the second secondary workflow to be actioned.

The main workflow will only move forward once both approvals are done.

But before we get ahead of ourselves, let's examine the workflow log immediately after that initial approvals.

 

Updating the Main Workflow Context after each approval:  SBPA API used as action
We'll be updating the main workflow's context after each approval and then comparing it against the total required count.

Here's a quick glimpse of what happens to the workflow context once the first approval is complete.

You can see the "donecount" increasing, which we'll use to compare against the total number of approvals needed.

We achieve this by updating the main workflow via its API, a process we've already covered in a previous blog post.

 

The Final Approval and Workflow Completion
Now, let's go a step deeper and understand the flow when the second, and final, approver takes action.

Once they approve, you'll see that the secondary workflow also completes, which then triggers the wait step in the main workflow.

This wait step is triggered via an API, a process we covered in detail in a previous blog post.

Understanding this particular use case of the wait step with an API is a critical aspect of this blog's core message.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Workflow Context After All Approvals
Now, let's carefully examine how the workflow context gets updated once all approvals are complete.

This is the crucial step that triggers the wait step and allows our main workflow to proceed.

In this scenario, the "donecount" becomes equal to the total number of required approvals, which in turn triggers the wait step API.

 

Handling Approval Outcomes: Positive and Negative Scenarios

so far We've explored the "positive scenario," where all approvers green-light the requests, leading to the main workflow's successful completion.

But what happens when an approver rejects a request?

Imagine a scenario where just one approver rejects. In such a case, the entire workflow must be rejected. My colleague, Mohit Bansal, detailed the design considerations for this rejection scenario in a previous blog post, so from a testing perspective, the approach remains similar.

However, in a rejection scenario, we need to take crucial additional steps:

  • Call the workflow cancel API: This immediately stops the main workflow.
  • Cancel any remaining open instances of secondary workflows: This is critical for designing a robust, production-ready complex workflow. Without canceling these, you could have orphaned workflow instances consuming resources or causing confusion.

     

  • Here's a quick look at how the system responds when any approver rejects: the main workflow is canceled, and all remaining open secondary workflow instances are also terminated.

We hope you enjoyed our blog series! We dove deep into complex workflow approval scenarios, exploring how to effectively leverage wait steps and workflow APIs to achieve robust "all-or-nothing" approval processes.

Please feel free to leave comments and share your thoughts. A big thank you to my colleague @mohit_bansal3  for his contributions, and stay tuned for more blogs on the latest innovations in this area!

Regards,

Adwait Fadnavis

entry.title: Unlocking the Future: How SAP Build Stands Out in Application Development
entry.content:
SAP Build stands out in the application development market due to its unique combination of low-code/no-code capabilities, deep integration with SAP ecosystems, AI-driven features, and focus on enterprise-grade scalability and governance. Below is a detailed analysis of why SAP Build differentiates itself from competitors like OutSystems, Mendix, or Microsoft Power Apps, emphasizing its strengths in the context of digital transformation and application development.

1. Unified Low-Code/No-Code Platform

  • Comprehensive Suite: SAP Build integrates three core components—SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Process Automation, and SAP Build Work Zone—into a single platform, enabling end-to-end development of applications, process automation, and business sites. Unlike competitors that often focus on one aspect (e.g., app development or automation), SAP Build provides a holistic solution, reducing the need for multiple tools.
  • Citizen Developer Empowerment: Its intuitive drag-and-drop interface and prebuilt templates allow business users with minimal technical expertise to create enterprise-grade applications. This democratizes development, enabling faster prototyping and reducing dependency on specialized developers, which competitors like OutSystems also offer but with less seamless SAP integration.

Standout Factor: The unified platform lowers the learning curve and streamlines workflows, making it ideal for businesses seeking rapid development without fragmented toolsets.

2. Deep Integration with SAP Ecosystem

  • SAP BTP Foundation: Built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Build seamlessly integrates with SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and other SAP solutions. This ensures a single source of truth, real-time data access, and compatibility with SAP’s clean core strategy, which minimizes technical debt during upgrades.
  • Extensibility: The Extensibility Wizard (introduced at SAP TechEd 2024) simplifies customization for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and is planned for SAP SuccessFactors, enabling tailored solutions without complex coding. Competitors like Mendix or Salesforce Lightning require additional integration layers to achieve similar SAP connectivity.
  • Third-Party Integration: SAP Build supports integration with non-SAP systems (e.g., Salesforce, Microsoft Dynamics) via SAP Integration Suite, with event-driven architecture planned for Q4 2025, enhancing real-time data flows.

Standout Factor: Native integration with SAP systems and support for hybrid environments make SAP Build the preferred choice for organizations heavily invested in SAP, unlike general-purpose platforms that require custom connectors.

3. AI-Driven Innovation

  • Joule Studio: SAP Build leverages AI through Joule Studio, enabling the creation of AI agents for predictive analytics, process automation, and intelligent decision-making. For example, it can automate complex workflows like invoice matching or predict inventory needs, a feature less prevalent in platforms like Appian or ServiceNow.
  • Embedded Intelligence: Integration with SAP AI Core allows developers to embed machine learning models into applications, enhancing functionality like demand forecasting or anomaly detection without external tools.
  • Natural Language Processing: Joule’s conversational AI simplifies user interactions, making app development and process automation accessible to non-technical users.

Standout Factor: AI-driven capabilities, tightly integrated with SAP’s enterprise data, provide a competitive edge over platforms with generic AI tools, delivering context-aware solutions for business-specific challenges.

4. Enterprise-Grade Scalability and Governance

  • Scalability: Built on SAP BTP’s cloud infrastructure, SAP Build supports enterprise-scale deployments with high availability and performance. It handles large-scale transformations, such as SAP S/4HANA migrations, with minimal latency, unlike smaller platforms like Bubble, which are better suited for startups.
  • Governance and Compliance: SAP Build includes built-in governance frameworks ensuring GDPR, SOC 2, and other compliance standards, critical for industries like finance or healthcare. This contrasts with platforms like Zoho Creator, which may require additional configurations for enterprise compliance.
  • Clean Core Strategy: SAP Build aligns with RISE with SAP’s clean core principles, ensuring extensions are upgradable and maintainable, reducing long-term costs compared to platforms like OutSystems, where customizations can lead to technical debt.

Standout Factor: Robust governance and scalability make SAP Build a trusted choice for large enterprises with complex regulatory and scalability needs.

5. Rapid Time-to-Value

  • Accelerated Development: SAP Build’s low-code approach reduces development time by 50-70% compared to traditional coding, as seen in case studies like Open Grid Europe, which achieved 50% faster onboarding using SAP Build Apps. Prebuilt templates and reusable components further speed up deployment.
  • Process Automation: SAP Build Process Automation combines RPA and workflow management, reducing manual tasks by up to 80% (e.g., financial close processes). This is faster than competitors like UiPath, which focus primarily on RPA without integrated app development.
  • Guided Methodologies: Integration with SAP Activate and SAP Signavio ensures structured implementation, minimizing project risks and accelerating time-to-value.

Standout Factor: The combination of low-code development, automation, and guided methodologies delivers faster ROI, particularly for SAP-centric transformations, compared to platforms with longer setup times.

6. Enhanced Collaboration and User Experience

  • Business-IT Collaboration: SAP Build bridges the gap between business and IT teams through shared development environments and visual tools, reducing miscommunication. For example, business users can prototype apps, while IT ensures governance, unlike Mendix, where IT involvement is often heavier.
  • SAP Build Work Zone: Provides role-based, personalized portals with SAP Fiori integration, improving user adoption by 25-40% (SAP benchmarks). This contrasts with platforms like Microsoft Power Apps, which offer less tailored UX for SAP environments.
  • Community and Support: SAP’s global partner ecosystem (e.g., EY, AG) and SAP Community provide extensive training and support, ensuring successful adoption compared to smaller platforms with limited ecosystems.

Standout Factor: Enhanced collaboration and user-centric design drive higher adoption rates, making SAP Build ideal for organizations prioritizing user engagement.

7. Competitive Positioning

Compared to key competitors:

  • OutSystems: Strong in low-code but lacks deep SAP integration and clean core alignment.
  • Mendix: Offers robust low-code features but requires more effort for SAP connectivity and compliance.
  • Microsoft Power Apps: Excels in Microsoft ecosystems but is less optimized for SAP environments.
  • ServiceNow: Focuses on IT service management, with limited app development flexibility compared to SAP Build’s comprehensive suite.

SAP Build’s tight integration with SAP BTP, AI capabilities, and focus on enterprise needs give it an edge for organizations leveraging SAP systems or pursuing large-scale digital transformations.

8. Real-World Impact

  • Open Grid Europe: Extended SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Build, achieving 50% faster onboarding and 20% reduced invoicing time.
  • Multinational Manufacturer: Used SAP Build with EY to standardize processes, improving efficiency across functions within 12 months.
  • Utilities Sector: Leveraged SAP Build for metering and billing apps, reducing process steps and enhancing real-time visibility.

Conclusion

SAP Build stands out in the application development market due to its unified low-code/no-code platform, deep SAP integration, AI-driven innovation, and enterprise-grade scalability. Its ability to accelerate development, automate processes, and ensure compliance while fostering collaboration makes it a leader for organizations undergoing SAP-centric or hybrid digital transformations. For businesses invested in SAP ecosystems or seeking rapid, scalable solutions, SAP Build delivers unmatched value, positioning it as a top choice in the competitive low-code market.

SAP Build  SAP AI Services SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation - How to transition to Shared Environment - Shared to all users
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We recently added a new option that allows to share an environment to all users. This would ease the transition from public environment to shared environment as explained in a previous blog post.

How it works?

You can create a shared environment as usual. Now in the sharing you have a new option:

After selecting this option, you can decide the rights applicable for all users:

The bare minimum right would be "Monitor". With "Deploy" a Process Automation Developer would be granted to deploy a project in this shared environment.

At the end you will have all the benefits from Shared Environment already mentioned here or here. It's also possible to update an existing shared environment with this option too.

Development Tenant VS. Production Tenant

  • In a "development tenant", you may enable this new shared environment with all rights... except administrate.
  • In a "production tenant", you may restrict this new shared environment with the right "execute" only.

Choice is yours as Process Automation Administrator.

More information about:

  • API Keys - help topic
  • Processes and Workflows within Environment - help topic
  • Manage Destinations - help topic
  • Triggers - help topic
  • Add an API trigger to a project - help topic
  • SAP Note for public environment sunset - https://me.sap.com/notes/3522611

entry.title: Automate Business Partner Updates with SAP Build
entry.content:
Update Business Partner Bank details in minutes — not days

Maintaining accurate Business Partner (BP) master data, especially bank details, is crucial yet challenging for businesses. Requests to update bank information traditionally involve manual validation, document verification, and data entry, leading to delays, errors, and increased costs.

With SAP Build Process Automation integrated with SAP Document Information Extraction (DOX) and generative AI capabilities, you can automate these processes, dramatically improving accuracy and response times. This blog demonstrates how your organization could automatically process Business Partner bank detail updates, ensuring rapid, error-free transactions while reserving manual review for exceptional cases.

Why Automation Matters

Bank detail updates for Business Partners—whether suppliers, citizens, employees or even customers—often entail cumbersome manual processes:

  • Collection of supporting documentation (bank certificate, identification documents).

  • Manual validation of names, bank details, and document authenticity.

  • Re-keying data, prone to human error.

  • Lengthy approval chains causing delays.

These tasks consume significant human resources and cause operational delays, financial risks, and compliance issues. Each manual intervention represents an additional cost, a source of potential errors, and delayed response times, negatively impacting business agility and stakeholder satisfaction.

Automated Process with SAP Build – How it Works

The SAP Build process, combined with Document Information Extraction and generative AI, offers a streamlined, automated approach:

  1. Request Submission: Users complete a form with their name, bank details, and upload required documents (bank certificate and identification). The form is surfaced in SAP Build Work Zone and uploaded files land instantly in SAP Document Management Service (DMS) for secure storage.

  2. Automated Parallel Document Processing:

    • Bank Certificate: Document Information Extraction Premium leverages generative AI for flexible extraction across different bank document formats.

    • Identification Document (National ID/DNI): Document Information Extraction Basic extracts standard data quickly and reliably.

  3. Verification and Validation:

    • The bank certificate undergoes an additional step for automated bank certificate’s digital signature verification, ensuring document authenticity.

    • The extracted data from documents and the initial form are compared automatically for consistency (e.g., exact match between names, account numbers).

  4. Conditional Rule:

    • If data matches precisely and verification succeeds, SAP Build automatically updates the Business Partner bank details in SAP S/4HANA.

    • If discrepancies are identified (such as a name mismatch), the request is routed to a human reviewer for manual approval or rejection through an approval form.

  5. Notification & Audit:

    • Automatic email notifications inform the requester of the approval status.

    • All processing steps, decisions, and document validations are archived for auditing purposes.


Benefits Achieved

  • Significant reduction in manual work, decreasing operational costs.

  • Faster processing time, increasing business agility.

  • Enhanced accuracy, reducing risk and ensuring compliance.

  • Improved team productivity, redirecting human resources to strategic tasks.



SAP BTP Components - Architecture

Below is the technical architecture used for this automated solution:

 This is just an illustrative example; your actual process and system integrations might differ depending on specific business requirements.



Conclusion & Next Steps

Automating Business Partner bank detail updates not only saves considerable time and cost but also enhances accuracy and compliance. With SAP Build and SAP BTP, you can automate critical processes easily, freeing your teams to focus on strategic tasks.

Start your automation journey today and experience the benefits firsthand.

entry.title: Manage SAP Build projects as part of your enterprise architecture
entry.content:
Recently, I transitioned from SAP Landscape Management to the product management team of SAP LeanIX. I landed in a fantastic team already hard at work on the integration between SAP LeanIX and SAP Build, and I was fortunate enough to help bring the first release across the finish line, which was announced last week.

Now, you can seamlessly connect your SAP Build instances with your SAP LeanIX workspaces, enabling automatic discovery of your SAP Build projects. This empowers enterprise architects to model these projects as application fact sheets, integrating them directly into their daily workflows within SAP LeanIX.

SAP Build is described as a "unified application development and process automation solution, enabling personalization and efficiency at scale." (source) It's a vital part of our customers' IT landscapes, complementing their existing SAP solutions. Consequently, the custom projects setup within SAP Build represent the unique, differentiating elements of their landscapes. Managing these projects alongside other SAP and non-SAP solutions within SAP LeanIX is a natural and essential next step.

Connecting the Dots

Rather than diving deep into the documentation, let me give you a quick overview of how to regularly discover your SAP Build projects within your SAP LeanIX workspace.

You'll need an instance of SAP Build Process Automation (even if you primarily use other SAP Build components) and an instance of SAP Cloud Management Service within your SAP BTP subaccount. The Cloud Management Service provides the context to the SAP BTP Global and Subaccount. Using service keys for these two instances, you can configure the new "SAP Build" integration within the admin area of SAP LeanIX.  Once you complete the onboarding wizard, your SAP Build projects will be automatically discovered and regularly updated.

The SAP Discovery inbox will present you with a list of all discovered projects. From there, you can link them to existing fact sheets or create new ones. The integration intelligently suggests the following fact sheet types:

  • Application: The project itself
  • IT Component: The technology used within the project (e.g. SAP Build Code)
  • Platform: SAP BTP, your global account, and the subaccount
  • Provider: SAP

I'm eager to hear your thoughts on this new integration! Does this address a pain point in your enterprise architecture work? What other challenges are you facing when managing extensions to your SAP solution portfolio?  Share your feedback in the comments below or on our roadmap item!

entry.title: Integrating Microsoft Services with SAP Build Process Automation using Microsoft 365 SDK & Graph API
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

 

Introduction

In the modern digital workplace, automation is no longer a luxury—it's a necessity. Businesses are continuously looking for ways to connect systems, eliminate manual effort, and accelerate decision-making. SAP Build Process Automation offers a powerful platform for automating business workflows, while Microsoft 365 services—like Outlook, SharePoint, OneDrive, and Excel—are deeply embedded in everyday enterprise operations.

This blog explores how to securely integrate SAP Build Process Automation with Microsoft Entra ID (formerly Azure AD), enabling direct access to Microsoft 365 services through either the Microsoft 365 SDK or Microsoft Graph API. This integration opens up automation possibilities across a wide range of business functions—from reading and sending emails, to accessing SharePoint documents, managing Excel files, and interacting with OneDrive storage.

Business Challenge: Automating Cross-Platform Enterprise Processes

Enterprise workflows often span multiple systems and platforms—SAP for business logic, and Microsoft 365 for communication, document management, and collaboration. However, bridging these platforms typically requires manual data transfers, file handling, and task coordination. These repetitive, error-prone activities consume valuable time and create bottlenecks in business processes.

Key challenges include:

  • Limited out-of-the-box automation SDK for Microsoft services.
  • Security and compliance risks due to manual authentication and permission handling.
  • Lack of centralized access to documents, emails, spreadsheets, and collaboration data from within automation tools.

With this integration, organizations can:

  • Automate email operations without outlook.
  • Interact with SharePoint and OneDrive to manage and retrieve files.
  • Automate Excel data processing and reporting.
  • Ensure secure and controlled access using Microsoft Entra ID authentication.

By embedding Microsoft 365 services directly into SAP Build Process Automation, businesses can streamline end-to-end workflows across systems, enhance productivity, and reduce IT overhead.

 

Azure App Registration in Microsoft Entra ID

Log in to the Azure Portal:

Navigate to https://portal.azure.com.

Open Microsoft Entra ID under Azure Services.

Image 1

From the left navigation pane, click on App registrations and then New registration.

Image 2

Image 3

Provide a Name for the app, choose the appropriate Supported account types, and set the Redirect URI type to Web.
Enter the following URI:
https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/oauth2/nativeclient.

Image 4

After registration:

Copy the Tenant ID and Client ID.

Generate a Client Secret by going to Certificates & Secrets.

These credentials are required for both Microsoft 365 SDK and Graph API integrations.

Image 5

Image 6

Method 1: Integrate Using Microsoft 365 SDK

Open SAP Build Process Automation Lobby and navigate to Control Tower > External Authentication.

Image 7

Click Create New Authentication, select Microsoft 365, and enter:

Tenant ID, Client ID, Client Secret

Choose the required Scopes based on your use case.

Image 8

Open the Desktop Agent on your local machine.

Image 9

Now Navigate to Settings → External Authentication → Select the Microsoft Authentication entry and Sign in using your user or technical account.

Image 10

Image 11

Image 12

If you're a Global Admin, you can check Consent on behalf of your organization during the first login prompt.

Note: Individual users can also provide consent for their own accounts.

Image 13

Set this authentication entry as your Default Connection in the Desktop Agent.

Image 14

In your Process Automation Project:

Add the Microsoft 365 Cloud SDK as a dependency.

Image 15

Use built-in activities such as:

Search Emails (e.g., filter by folder: Inbox or by subject)

Send Email (e.g., specify recipient, subject, and body)

Image 16

Upon execution, you can validate:

Emails fetched from the inbox

Outgoing emails successfully delivered to recipients

Image 17

Image 18

Image 19

Image 20

Image 21

Method 2: Integrate Using Microsoft Graph API

For more advanced or customized use cases, you can use the Microsoft Graph API to interact with Microsoft services programmatically.

Permissions Setup:

Review and assign required permissions from Microsoft Graph API Reference docs.

Use Graph Explorer to test API calls and review responses.

If permissions require admin approval, click Grant admin consent for Default Directory.

 

Image 22

Image 23

Image 24

Image 25

Image 26

Image 27

Image 28

Generate Access Token:

Use your Tenant ID, Client ID, and Client Secret to form the authentication request.

Refer to standard OAuth 2.0 token generation flow (as shown in Image 29).

Image 29

Image 30

Call the Graph API:

Use the obtained Access Token to make API calls to endpoints such as:
https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/users/{UserID}/mailFolders('Inbox')/messages

Fetch email data or other resources as needed (refer to Image 32 for sample response).

Image 31

Image 32

Conclusion: Unified Automation Across SAP and Microsoft Ecosystems

Integrating SAP Build Process Automation with Microsoft Entra ID and Microsoft 365 services delivers a robust foundation for enterprise-grade automation. Whether using the Microsoft 365 SDK for a plug-and-play experience, or leveraging Microsoft Graph API for advanced customization, this approach allows seamless access to:

  • Outlook – for reading, searching, and sending emails
  • SharePoint & OneDrive – for retrieving, storing, and managing documents
  • Excel – for accessing and automating spreadsheet-based operations
  • Teams & Calendar (optional) – for integrating communication and scheduling meetings

Security is built-in through OAuth-based authentication and consent management, ensuring compliance while enabling automation at scale.

By centralizing access and automating repetitive actions across Microsoft and SAP platforms, businesses reduce complexity, minimize errors, and free up valuable resources. This is more than a technical integration—it's a strategic enabler for digital transformation.

entry.title: Gamechanger Alert: Meet SAP Joule Studio for Real-World Impact
entry.content:
As someone who's still fairly new to SAP and learning about all it has to offer, I recently came across SAP Joule Studio—a tool that honestly surprised me. It’s part of SAP’s growing focus on AI, but instead of being just a tech buzzword, it’s something practical. Something helpful. Something that actually makes life easier.

So I thought I’d share what I’ve learned so far, for anyone else who’s curious like me.

 

What is SAP Joule Studio?

SAP Joule Studio is a low-code/no-code platform that lets you create AI-powered agents—little digital helpers that live inside your SAP system and support everyday tasks. These agents can:

  • Answer questions using real SAP data
  • Send reminders or alerts
  • Trigger workflows based on events
  • Help users navigate complex processes

The best part? You don’t need to be a developer to build one.

All you need is a good understanding of a business problem, and Joule Studio helps you turn that into a solution using easy visual tools.

 

Why This Is a Game-Changer (With Real Use Cases)

What really got me excited was seeing how real-world teams can use this tool to solve day-to-day challenges. Here are a few examples that really stood out to me:

✅HR & Employee Self-Service

  • Use Case: An AI agent that answers common HR questions like “How many vacation days do I have left?”, “What’s the process to update my bank details?”, or “When does my probation end?”
  • Impact: Reduces emails to HR, gives instant answers, and improves employee satisfaction.

✅Onboarding Assistant

  • Use Case: An AI agent that guides a new joiner through their first week—showing them how to complete paperwork, introducing them to teammates, and sending daily checklists.
  • Impact: Makes onboarding smoother, especially for remote hires or global teams.

✅Procurement Alerts

  • Use Case: A smart assistant that watches for delays from key suppliers and notifies procurement managers if a PO is stuck or overdue.
  • Impact: Keeps procurement responsive and improves relationships with vendors.

✅Project Management Summary

  • Use Case: A daily AI briefing that tells project leads about overdue tasks, timesheet gaps, or resource bottlenecks.
  • Impact: Saves hours of manual tracking and keeps teams aligned.

✅Compliance Checker

  • Use Case: A bot that checks which employees haven't completed their mandatory training or signed policy documents, and sends them a reminder.
  • Impact: Helps HR stay compliant without manual follow-ups.

✅IT Helpdesk Agent

  • Use Case: An agent that answers questions like “How do I reset my SAP password?” or “Where do I raise a ticket?”
  • Impact: Cuts down ticket volume for IT support and empowers users.

These aren’t just theoretical—they’re real issues we see in companies every day. And Joule Studio gives you a way to solve them quickly, without coding or waiting on IT.

 

Why Clients Will Love It Too

For clients, Joule Studio brings:

  • Self-service power to their SAP users
  • Less dependency on IT for small tasks
  • Smarter workflows with reminders, alerts, and guidance
  • Faster onboarding and training for new team members
  • Consistency across geographies and business units

AI becomes something helpful, not something scary or complex. It empowers users instead of overwhelming them.

 

Where You Can See It in Action

If you're like me and prefer learning visually, I highly recommend this official demo:

 SAP Joule Studio – AI for Everyone (YouTube)

You can also explore SAP’s official product page for more examples and how-to guides:
 SAP Joule Studio – Official Page

These are great starting points with visuals and real examples.

 

Getting Started with Joule Studio

If you’re ready to try it:

  1. Make sure your system is running on SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform).
  2. Go into SAP Build and access Joule Studio.
  3. Start by creating a small AI agent for a common task.
  4. Train it using real process examples and test in Preview mode.
  5. Roll it out with the right user permissions.

 

 

 

Remember—you don’t need to be technical. You just need to understand your business and what people are struggling with. Joule Studio helps you close that gap.

 

Final Thoughts (From One Learner to Another)

I’m still exploring SAP, still learning, and still asking questions. But tools like Joule Studio give me hope, not just for where tech is going, but for how we can make it work for people.

This isn’t about replacing humans—it’s about supporting them with small, smart helpers that remove friction and free up time.

If you're also exploring SAP tools and wondering where to start with AI, this might just be the right place. Try building a simple use case and see what it unlocks for your team.

And if you’ve tried it, I’d really love to hear what you’ve built. Let’s share and learn together, because the best ideas often come from the people closest to the problem.

 

#SAPJoule, #JouleStudio, #SAPBTP, #AIinSAP, #Gamechanger, #NoCodeAI, #SAPBuild, #EnterpriseAI, #DigitalTransformation, #SAPCommunity

entry.title: New SAP Build Process Automation content for side-by-side extensions with flexible workflows
entry.content:
My colleagues published a SAP Build Process Automation action package "Flexible Workflow Scenario Notifications Action" on SAP Business Accelerator Hub and in the SAP Build Store so that it becomes easier for Citizen Developer to discover and consume it.

It oﬀers an action for an outcome driven extension workﬂow and makes it easier to combine ﬂexible workﬂows from SAP S/4HANA with SAP Build Process Automation capabilities.

From a use case perspective, you could think of including process participants from outside (like external project managers) into the SAP S/4HANA Process. Or you include centrally managed services from SAP BTP like a Rules Service or Joule Skills into your SAP S/4HANA workﬂow project. Or you like to leverage ML services like the recommendation capability of SAP Task Center, which is only available for SAP Build Process Automation tasks? For the blog I took the use case with process participants from outside to explain the possibilities.

In line with side-by-side extensibility ﬂexible workﬂow oﬀers an activitytype "extension step" which can be implemented by flexible workflow scenarios to offer side-by-side extension. It is guideline for all scenario developers to enable it.

I will give a short overview and add some points in addition to the oﬃcial documentation.

The solution architecture gives an overview on the connection between Sales Order Creation in SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP. Over the ﬂexible workﬂow capability of SAP Business Workﬂow it is possible to start an extension process and get back the result / outcome from SAP Build Process Automation .

Configuration in SAP S/4HANA starts with definition of decision reasons for sales orders. In our use case we want to start a flexible workﬂow which is the internal approval solution. After setting an internal approval reason a BAdI checks after saving the Sales Order if an approval is necessary. If true a start event is thrown and checks if a workﬂow is deﬁned in the Manage Workﬂow Application for our scenario. If the scenario contains an extension step, the business process expert is able to configures an extension step with a process deﬁnition from SAP Build Process Automation from the connected BTP subaccount. During runtime when the flow comes to the extension, a SAP Build Process Automation workflow is started via api and a standardize payload. 

For shared environments an API Trigger is needed. In the extension workﬂow of our use case we derive the complete sales order header data over an API call to SAP S/4HANA and use this data for Agent Determination. After agent determination via decision table a user decision is modelled with two outcomes.

After the user decision took place we need to set the outcome via script and use it in the action content package. Go to SAP Build Store. Search for "flexible".

Click on the action project for review the details.

Add the action to your project.

To use the action and point to the correct ABAP-Backend-System:

  1. define a destination variable in the SAP Build Process Automation project.
  2. define a destination in the BTP Cockpit to the ABAP-Backend-System(s)
  3. map the destination to the destination variable during deployment of the project.

Define the workflowInstanceId in the context and fill it from the start payload. For the names of the outcomes you need to look up the flexible workflow scenario or check the documentation of the used scenario. If it is custom build in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition or SAP S/4HANA (like in this blog) check your implementation of the extension step and fill the outcomes accordingly.

Please be aware that the development livecycle of the projects on SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP is independent. We work on further enhancements to simplify the integration via the extensibility wizard and also on more features to enrich the possibilities. So stay tuned. A big thanks to all colleagues supporting the integration.

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation – Configuring Microsoft 365 email provider for SMTP mail destination
entry.content:
A common use case for SAP Build Process Automation is email communication to end users. To implement the Email step in your processes, you need both an active mail server and a properly configured destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Currently, SAP Build Process Automation supports three authentication methods for email services:

  • Basic Authentication
  • OAuth2 Password Grant
  • OAuth2 Client Credentials Flow

It's important to note that Microsoft 365 no longer supports Basic Authentication, having shifted to more secure authentication protocols. While Basic Authentication remains viable with other email providers, Microsoft environments require alternative approaches. For those interested, the OAuth2 Password Flow implementation has been documented in a previous article.

This guide will walk you through the comprehensive steps needed to configure a Microsoft 365 account as an SMTP mail destination using the OAuth2 Client Credentials Flow, following the official documentation on configuring SMTP Mail Destinations. One benefit of using this grant flow, is that Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) can remain enabled.

Prerequisites

  • A tenant in Microsoft Azure Entra ID (Active Directory).
  • A user with an active Outlook 365 subscription.

 

Microsoft Azure configuration

Along these steps, I will be using a new tenant, with unconfigured users and will manage this using the admin account.

Create a Microsoft Azure Active Directory Application

Step 1: Access the Azure Portal.

Step 2: Open Microsoft Entra Id.

Step 3: Navigate to Manage and then select App Registrations.

Step 4: Select New Registration.

Step 5: Provide an application name, select Accounts in any organizational directory (Any Microsoft Entra ID tenant - Multitenant) and register.

On the following page, you will find the TenantId and ClientId. Save them, you will need them later.

Step 6: We will now create the SecretId. Under Manage, select Certificates & Secrets.

Step 7: Create a New client secret. Add a description and select an expiration date.

Save the secret value generated, this will be used as your SecretId.

Step 8: Let's now add the correct API permission. Go under Manage and select API permissions.

Step 9: Select Add a permission.

Step 10: Select APIs my organization uses.

Step 11: Search for Office 365 Exchange Online and select it.

Step 12: Select Application permissions and search for SMTP.SendAsApp, select it and add the permission.

Step 13: Now Grant admin consent for Contoso.

You should see the status updated as follows:

We have finished configuring the application. Now we will configure the user.

 

Configure Admin Center to enable SMTP Auth

As mentioned at the beginning, the SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is the standard protocol used for sending email. We will now configure the user to authorize it.

Step 14: Access Microsoft admin portal. 

Step 15: Expand Users and select Active Users.

Step 16: Select the user you want to configure.

Step 17: Under Mail, select Manage email apps.

Step 18: Make sure the box Authenticated SMTP is checked, if not, check it and save.

The configuration of the user is now done, there is now one more step before you can send mails.

 

Register service principals in Exchange

We will now be using the powershell to execute the commands from this learn Microsoft page: Authenticate an IMAP, POP or SMTP connection using OAuth.

Step 19: Make sure you're running your powershell as administrator. Then, install and import the ExchangeOnlineManagement module.

Install-Module -Name ExchangeOnlineManagement
Import-module ExchangeOnlineManagement

Step 20: Connect to ExchangeOnline using your TenantId, the one saved from earlier (step 5).

Connect-ExchangeOnline -Organization <tenantId>

A pop-up window should open asking you for your credentials and your authentication code. Once signed-in, you should see the above.

Step 21: Register the Microsoft Entra application's service principal in Exchange.

New-ServicePrincipal -AppId <APPLICATION_ID> -ObjectId <OBJECT_ID>

To find the ApplicationId and ObjectId, you will have to go back to the Azure Portal, go to Microsoft Entra ID and Enterprise Applications under Manage.

Select the application you've created earlier and use the following ids.

Once it has runned, you should see:

Step 22: Now add the specific mailboxes in the tenant that will be allowed to be accessed by your application. Use the user from step 16. This command might take time to reflect and can take up to several hours to be propagated into Microsoft's system, so don't rush into the testing 😉. It took ~1 hour in this guide for this step to be applied.

Add-MailboxPermission -Identity "<YOUR_USER>" -User <OBJECT_ID> -AccessRights FullAccess

Done, you should be all set ! Let's now test it (considering you've waited long enough).

 

SAP Build Process Automation configuration and testing

Add all the information you've got from the steps above in your destination, then save.

To get the properties correct, follow the steps on the SAP help portal. Also note that for the OAuth2 Client Credentials flow, the scope is: https://outlook.office.com/.default. The token service url is https://login.microsoftonline.com/<TenantId>/oauth2/v2.0/token.

You can now go under Control Tower, select Mail Server, click on Send Test Mail.

Choose your recipient, press Send Test Mail.

 

And voilà:

entry.title: What’s New in SAP Build Q2 2025 - Release Highlights
entry.content:
Q2 brought a wave of innovations to SAP Build, including improvements across governance, integration and user experience. We also had several announcements in the spotlight at SAP Sapphire 2025 around new AI capabilities, unified pricing, and of course Joule Studio, which lets you create custom Joule skills and AI agents. In case you missed it, check out our roundup of key updates from SAP Sapphire and the announcement of Joule Studio.

If you’re interested in shaping the future of SAP Build, we’ve introduced the SAP Build Discovery Initiative 2025. We’re looking for participants to meet with product teams, test early prototypes and bring your perspective to influence innovations from day one. Find more info here.

Now let’s dive into the Top 10 release innovations from Q2 2025!

Enhanced governance capabilities

1. Empowering business users to maintain rules through an application

In Process Automation projects, business users are often the content owners of decisions and the logic behind business rules. While the SAP Build Lobby is a powerful environment, it can also be challenging to navigate and maintain the content of separate artifacts. 

Now IT and dev teams can give business users access to decisions via a purpose-built application, which is opened in SAP Build Work Zone. By empowering business users to access the logic this way, it helps mitigate risks of unauthorized changes, while also reducing delays around the change management process.

Manage decisions through a purpose-built application

2. Improved governance with approval flows & multi-node project transport

Strong governance frameworks are essential to ensure that your development activities remain secure and compliant. We have now released two features that support greater control and quality assurance:

  • Governance approval flows: This enables administrators to control who is authorized to create or transport projects across tenants or sub-accounts. The approval process is fully customizable, allowing organizations to implement quality gates aligned with their specific governance and compliance requirements.
  • Multi-node project transport: Approvers can now move SAP Build projects (apps, processes, automations) through a controlled Dev -> Test -> Production landscape, with approval steps and quality checks at each stage. This ensures dev teams are moving projects securely and efficiently across tenants.

Governance approval flows

Seamless interoperability and AI-powered integration

3. Importing Business Process Model & Notation (BPMN) to generate process artifacts automatically 

Great news for our automation enthusiasts – it’s now possible to import BPMN processes from other tools into SAP Build! BPMN is the industry standard for defining workflows, decisions, and interactions across systems and teams. 

Now process designers can migrate existing BPMN processes from SAP Signavio, SAP NetWeaver, and IBM to generate process artifacts automatically. This long-awaited transportability helps to speed up the logic creation significantly, as well as acting as the bridge between SAP Build and other process modeling tools. 

To get started with BPMN process imports, see the Help Portal.Import BPMN processes into SAP Build

4. Improved SAP SuccessFactors integration with event discovery

From the SAP Build Lobby, developers can manage and connect SAP and non-SAP systems through the Unified Customer Landscape (UCL). Now in the UCL, developers can discover business events from SAP Cloud Application Event Hub, as well as SAP SuccessFactors solutions. This improved integration supports more relevant scenarios for HR processes, such as employee onboarding and compensation management. 

5. AI grounding in company-specific content for tailored responses

This feature makes it possible to base Joule copilot and other embedded AI capabilities on up-to-date documents and user-created content in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition through the RAG (retrieval augmented generation) method. Rather than giving generic responses, it provides end users with more accurate and domain-specific content.

AI grounding within Joule copilot

6. Joule-based assistant to easily migrate SAP HANA applications to CAP

For simplified innovation across services, the SAP HANA Application Migration Assistant is a new extension available in SAP Build Code. This automates the conversion of XS classic applications into CAP-based services to accelerate modernization and help businesses adopt cloud-native architectures faster.

For more info, see Product Updates for SAP Build Code – June 2025 Edition

Optimized user experience and accessibility across devices

7. SAP Mobile Start as the unified mobile access point for users

SAP Mobile Start addresses the challenge of fragmented access to enterprise applications and information for mobile users. The connection of SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition ensures that users have consistent and secure access to business applications, tasks, and notifications, regardless of their location or device.

 8. Preview SAPUI5 updates for better UX management

To address the need for more controlled testing, we’ve introduced the ability to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone. Admins can activate the preview in a staging or dev tenant, validate compatibility and confirm everything works as expected before go-live – ensuring agile development, reduced downtime, and better user experience management.

For more info, read the blog post.

SAPUI5 version preview in SAP Build Work Zone

9. Local Entry Point (LEP) to simplify access to standalone sites

The new Local Entry Point (LEP) concept of SAP Build Work Zone simplifies how SaaS application providers integrate business solutions into SAP BTP. Providers can generate a standalone entry-point site in the consumer’s subaccount, eliminating the extra efforts and complexity required to set up their own instances.

To get started, see the Help Portal.

10. Updates to Mobile Development Kit for enhanced UI, APIs and more

The latest release to SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) has brought several new updates for customers, including the newest version of Mobile Services Client in the Google Play Store and Apple App Store. Among the newest enhancements to UI is support for donut charts, providing a new way to visualize data and emphasize different aspects of datasets.

See all the latest updates: What’s New in Mobile Development Kit client 25.6

Ready to see these in action?

To learn more and see live demos of the latest release highlights, join us for the next What’s New in SAP Build Q2 2025 Webinar! 

👉Register for your preferred time slot:

  • July 17th, 9:00AM – 10:00AM CEST: https://sap.to/60414diDL
  • July 17th, 5:00PM – 6:00PM CEST: https://sap.to/60434diDF

entry.title: Automating Email with SAP Build Process Automation and Outlook Bot
entry.content:
In this blog, I will walk you through how I built an outlook automation bot that : -
i) Opens Microsoft Outlook.
ii) Sends a repetitive message with  .docx file attached.
iii) Closes outlook.
iv) Is released and deployed through the SAP Build lobby.

Creating a new automation project
First of all log into SAP Build Lobby.
Click create -> Automated Process->Automation and click on next


Name your project as ‘OutlookEmailAutomation’.
Provide a short description  as “ Bot to send daily emails with attachment via outlook”.

Click on ‘Review’ and then ‘Create’.

Designing the Automation Bot
In the automation section, click create -> automation and give the agent version


name it ‘sendemailbot’ and add description as ‘ bot for email automation’

Click on create.

Click on setting option, go to dependencies and  click on add -> Add a business process project dependency ( it is necessary to do this as then only we can get the different operations related to outlook in our tools section )

and then add ‘outlook sdk’


Add these steps by drag & drop from the tools section ;-

  1. i) Open outlook instance
    ii) Send email(Outlook)
    iii) Release outlook instance

In automation details section, go to input/output and set one input parameter for storing the document location which is going to be attached in the mail

In Send Email(Outlook) properties, fill all necessary details
( like In emailitemparameter add custom data,
set email fields
attach file path( here add the filepath variable for storing file location))


Test the bot locally
Click on test button and give the filepath ( i.e. the folder location)
e.g.


Ensure that there are no errors.


Release the automation
Navigate to project overview
Click release – set version 1.0.0
Add release notes : “ Initial release of outlook email bot”.

Finally Deploy the Bot
Go to deployments tab in the build lobby.
choose your bot and deploy version 1.0.0.
Assign it to a Desktop Agent that has outlook installed.
Trigger via manual execution or by scheduled trigger(e.g. every morning 9:00 am).

Benefits of this automation :-
It will save daily manual effort.
It reduces errors in repeated email content.
It ensures consistent report attachment.
It works even with outlook desktop app – no server-side integration required.

entry.title: Primeira edição do SAP XPERIENCE CWB: um sábado para ficar na história!
entry.content:
Neste sábado, dia 05 de julho, realizamos com muito orgulho a primeira edição do SAP XPERIENCE CWB, um evento idealizado e promovido pela SAP Community Curitiba.

Foi uma manhã de conexão, aprendizado e muita troca de experiências, com foco em tecnologia, comunidade e, claro, aquele toque especial da cultura curitibana.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Logo na chegada, os participantes foram recepcionados pelos nossos curadores @SimoneAzevedo  e @TiagoFelipe , que conduziram o credenciamento com muita simpatia — e ainda entregaram um brigadeiro como mimo de boas-vindas. Um toque doce para começar bem o dia!

☕Networking com café e boas conversas

Curitiba nos presenteou com uma manhã típica: friozinho e céu nublado. Para aquecer, oferecemos um coffee especial, onde o networking rolou solto.
Durante esse momento, o mentor @LuizSouza  já começou a interagir com os participantes, criando um clima super acolhedor.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

👥Abertura oficial

Iniciamos o evento com uma fala do curador @TiagoFelipe , que trouxe um overview sobre o propósito e os valores da SAP Community.

Na sequência, Alinie, representando a PUCPR — nossa grande parceira que gentilmente cedeu a estrutura para a realização do evento — ela compartilhou alguns cursos que a PUCPR pode oferecer ao nosso ecossistema.

 

🧠 Mão na massa com BTP

O mentor @LuizSouza  então assumiu o palco para conduzir um hands-on prático e intenso sobre Workflow com SAP BTP.  Com muita didática, generosidade e paixão, ele guiou os participantes por uma experiência de aprendizado real. Todo mundo literalmente colocou a mão na massa!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

🎁Sorteios e agradecimentos

Após o hands-on, tivemos o momento dos sorteios de cursos incríveis, gentilmente oferecidos pelos apoiadores do evento.

 Foi uma forma simbólica, mas muito especial, de retribuir o engajamento e entusiasmo da comunidade.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

🙌Encerramento com energia lá em cima

Fechamos a manhã com o sentimento de missão cumprida e energia renovada. A vibe estava contagiante, e a troca entre os participantes mostrou a força da comunidade quando ela se une em prol do conhecimento.

🔥Networking pós-evento: after na Fazenda Churrascada

E para quem achou que o dia já tinha sido completo... ainda teve mais!

O networking continuou em um animado after na Fazenda Churrasda, onde os participantes puderam relaxar, confraternizar e fortalecer ainda mais os laços criados durante o evento.

Nada como um bom churrasco para fechar com chave de ouro essa experiência inesquecível!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Agradecemos imensamente a todos que acreditaram, apoiaram e participaram desta primeira edição do SAP XPERIENCE CWB.

Foto com a Mariana (segunda )da PUCPR que nos apoio desde o inicio.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

💬Que esta tenha sido a primeira de muitas edições! Curitiba mostrou que tem uma comunidade forte, ativa e cheia de vontade de crescer junto.

Nos vemos no próximo encontro!

entry.title: Import BPMN and Generate Executable Process with SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
Introduction :

  • Import Business Process Model and Notation (BPMN) models and generate process artifacts automatically, for example, from SAP Signavio solutions or Netweaver BPM tools or any tool which supports process model creation as BPMN and export of the BPMN files.
  • Convert BPMN process models into an executable business process within SAP Build Process Automation

Enterprise automation with SAP Solutions:

To help customers stay ahead of the competition, SAP offers enterprise automation, a framework that combines the value of SAP Integration Suite, SAP Signavio, and SAP Build. Enterprise Automation allow customers to identify, model, integrate and automate processes end to end across heterogeneous landscapes. For more details on Enterprise Automation, please refer here.

 

Lets take an example of a process modelled in Signavio Process Manager and see how the export of the process model from Signavio Process Manager as BPMN file can be done and import of the same BPMN  file to SAP Build Process Automation helps customers with the Model to Execute pattern. This important feature helps customers to migrate their processes easily to SAP Build Process Automation without having to recreate the process from scratch.

Process Model  :

Lets take a typical use case,   Capital expenditure or capital expense (abbreviated capex, CAPEX, or CapEx), which is the money an organization or corporate entity spends to buy, maintain, or improve its fixed assets, such as buildings, vehicles, equipment, or land .

The CapEx approval process helps companies decide if big purchases are worthwhile. Most companies require multiple authorizations to approve capital expenditures, or at least those over a certain amount. This system helps prevent fraud and unnecessary purchases.

It starts off when a person or team submits a  CapEx Request Form. From there, the request usually goes through many departments on its way to the CFO/CEO. Once the CFO/CEO receives it, they take a close look and make the final call on whether to approve the purchase.

An existing Signavio customer would have modelled this process in Signavio Process Manager and executed in Signavio Process Governance. Now to switch to a low code tool SAP Build Process Automation, all that the customer has to do are outlined below :

  1.  Export process from Signavio Process Manager/Signavio Process Governance as bpmn file 
  2. Import the bpmn file to SAP Build Process Automation.(Note: If you would like to do everything yourself, you can just create a Build process automation project and proceed to Point 5. Point 1-4 helps you with a base project with some required artifacts)
    1. Go to https://github.com/SAP-samples/process-automation-enablement/tree/main/Project and download the "BPMN Import.zip" file and "CapEx_Process.bpmn" file which is exported in the previous step from Signavio Process Manager.
    2. Extract the BPMN Import.mtar file inside BPMN Import.zip
    3. Go to your Build Lobby and import the mtar file 
    4. The base project with the required artifacts are created for you .
    5. Import the CapEx_Process.bpmn file with the Import -> BPMN Process feature
  3. Do the manual configurations to make it executable ready 
    1. The imported CapEx process in Build Process Automation will have placeholders for forms, approval forms and subprocess etc., as the compatibility of the artifacts may not be one-one match with the other tool from where the process is modelled originally, in this case, Signavio Process Manager. 
    2. These placeholders will have to replaced with actual artifacts in Build Process Automation to make it executable ( Note : If the placeholders are not replaced with actual artifacts, process cannot be executed) 
    3. Guidance on what is the actual artifact is provided in placeholders . For example, if the placeholder will have to replaced with a Form, the option will say "Replace with Form", or if it has to be replaced with Action (for Service Task), it will read "Replace with Action" so on and so forth.
    4. Artifacts where there is direct compatibility like script task , mail task, conditions branch will be replaced with appropriate artifacts and content wherever applicable . 
    5. Replace the "Create Request Form" placeholder with Form
    6. Check and adjust Script task - Check Total Price of Items 
    7. Replace the "Procurement Review Subprocess" placeholder with Subprocess
    8. Replace the "Procurement Review" placeholder with Approval form 
    9. Replace the "Finance Review Approval" placeholder with Approval Form similar to the above step
    10. Check the Condition for Total price based on which CEO Approval is triggered 
    11. Replace the "CEO Approval" placeholder with Approval form similar to steps 8 and 9.
    12. Check the Mail task "CapEx Approval Status Mail" and adjust the body of the email and add recipients to make it ready for execution 
  4. Execute the process .
    1. Save and Release the project
    2. Deploy the project 
    3. Now the project is ready to be executed.
    4. Run the project from Monitoring page 

Happy Migration of your process to SAP Build Process Automation with reduced Model to Execution time !

entry.title: We asked, you answered. Customer views on SAP BTP.
entry.content:
A little over three years ago the SAP BTP team decided to develop a review page for SAP BTP with Trust Radius, a leader in enterprise software reviews, so that we might capture some feedback directly from customers concerning their satisfaction with their investment in SAP BTP, and which we hoped would also include their thoughts about the effect that use of the platform and its services was having on their own businesses.

Having now surpassed over 500 reviews, and even more ratings, as well as collecting several awards on the way, including the recent “Top Rated 2025” award among others, I thought that now would be a good time to reflect on some of the feedback that customers have left in their reviews of SAP BTP. 

So, here’s the first of what I hope will be a series of blogs which will look at some of the reviews that customers have left with Trust Radius about their experience with SAP BTP.  And I’ve decided to do this by taking a look from different organizational viewpoints, given that reviews have been left by individuals from various roles, in different parts of the business, and from organizations of all sizes.

SAP BTP in customers’ words

Let’s start with reviews from different types and sizes of organizations, and in in our customers’ own words here’s what they say:

“(Company) uses BTP to manage HTML applications that are then displayed in a customer and supplier portal, we also use BTP to manage users accessing the portal and all this connected to a S4/HANA…SAP Business Technology Platform is the right tool to manage sites, applications, users and everything you can imagine in the cloud and non-cloud world, from my point of view BTP is very well focused and has everything that a tool has to have and today” Large media production organization, 5*review, 10000+ employees, June 2025

“SAP Business Technology Platform is being used in our organization …It's low code/ no-code so easier to integrate HANA server with non-SAP server for data sync and rapid development of the product for the production. It helps us to get real time insight of data…we connected our SAP servers like mm, litmos to the legacy system we have like dynamics and salesforce, which helped us a lot during data migration and system integration. It helps the entire business automation process. Easier to analyze and manage the data with beautiful dashboard. After having this much still it's cost effective” Mid-sized engineering company 5* review, 501-1000 employees, April 2025

“BTP is used to improvise customer experience and creating automated processes across line of business and also enhancing the data and for the advanced analytics for helping in better decision-making and also BTP is a key tool for enabling the digital transformation to achieve better integration for creating more value for data and seamless flow between SAP and non SAP applications” Large IT & services business 5* review, 1001-5000 employees, May 2025

Of course, these are just a few of many reviews hosted on the SAP BTP page on the Trust Radius platform, and my selection criteria was simply one of organizational size. But even within just this small sample of customer reviews, it’s clear that SAP BTP is being used for different use cases across these differing organizations, but still delivering value through integration, automation and analytics capabilities.

Next time I’ll take a look from another viewpoint, but meanwhile, if you’re already intrigued and wish to see for yourself how customers are using SAP BTP then please feel free to browse the library of SAP BTP reviews on Trust Radius, or read more about SAP BTP on our website.

Happy reading!

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
entry.content:
The APIs for process automation are quite important to building integration scenarios with processes. But many people do not know how to get started, and even experienced users do not know how to work with environments or how to handle authentication or when an API key is needed.

So here is a guide to the APIs.

NOTE: I assume that you already know how to work with process automation, and you know the ins and outs of creating and triggering process projects using the SAP Build UI.

 

What can you do with APIs

If you just use forms to trigger a process, and then the process runs with actions and approval forms, you may not need to use the APIs. But most sophisticated processes will require you to make use of the APIs. So here is a list of some of things you can do with the APIs:

  • Trigger a process (sending in input values)
  • Get the status of a process instance
  • Get the context and execution log of a process instance
  • Change the status of a process instance (such as suspend or cancel)
  • Get a list of existing processes
  • Get a list of open user tasks
  • Approve or reject an approval form
  • Execute any form, and select which button of the form to simulate pressing
  • Call a decision (business rule) to get the appropriate output
  • Get a list of automation jobs that were run
  • ... and much more

 

Where to get information on APIs

The best place to go to get basic reference information about the APIs is, of course, the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Search for Process Automation, and then under APIs you will see the package of APIs.

Click the SAP Build Process Automation package, and you will see 1 OData API and 6 REST API. The key APIs are the REST APIs. 

Here's a link to get to the SAP Build Process Automation package directly.

 

Authentication and Permissions

The most complex part of working with the APIs is the authentication, and understanding the types of authentication and what each enables you to do.

2 Main Authentication Methods

There are 2 main ways to perform OAuth2 authentication:

  • Client Credentials, where you are signing in as the service, which has essentially admin rights (but not complete access to all information)
  • User Token, where you are signing in as a user (you) with whatever rights you have been given, both in terms of process automation roles and permissions in a specific SAP Build environment (more on environments later)

Why is this important?

Because you often want to know who the user is who is calling the API. For example, when triggering a process, the user who makes the API call is the one listed in the Monitoring tab. If that's not important, you can use client credentials with a service key.

Or, if you are retrieving workflow instances from an environment, only a member from that environment with the correct permissions can access the workflow instances. Using client credentials with the client id/secret will not work.

Client Credentials

To connect, with Client Credentials, you send a Client ID and Client Secret, derived from the service key.

In the cockpit, where you created an instance of the SAP Build Process Automation service, you need to create a service key. 

You only need supply a name for the key.

Once you create the key, you can view the key's detail by clicking View.

This displays something like this:

You only need the following fields to log in:

  • api: The host of the APIs
  • clientid: Username
  • clientsecret: Password
  • url: Authentication URL to get the authorization token (the URL is this URL with /oauth/token appended)

So if you were setting up a destination, this is how it would work:

User Token

But many times, perhaps most times, you do not want to use a service user but you want to know who is making the call. This is important, for example, if the call is to approve the task, so only the user to whom the task is assigned should be updating the task. Or, as we mentioned above, only a real member of an environment can retrieve workflow instances from a shared environment.

With a destination, the only change you need to make is to change the Authentication field to OAuth2JWTBearer, and this will make sure to retrieve and send a token for the current user. All other destination fields are the same.

Environments

With the relatively new shared environments (i.e., all environments except Public), you sometimes need to indicate in the API call to which environment you are making the call to. For example, a process may be deployed to multiple environments, so when you call to trigger it, you need to specify in which environment to trigger it.

To do this, you add this query parameter:

?environmentId=MyEnvironment

Similarly, if you want to retrieve all the process instances from a particular environment, your API URL might look like this:

https://spa-api-gateway-bpi-us-prod.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=danielshared

 

Try Out on Accelerator Hub

Let's try to access our SAP Build Process Automation process instances from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Go to the GET workflow-instances API. On the left menu, click Workflow Instances, and then select the first API call.

Click Add New Environment on the right, and fill in the details using the values from your service key.

Call the environment My Trial BTP, select the authentication domain for your tenant (for my trial account it was http://authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/) and then when entering the consumer subdomain, only enter the subdomain for your subaccount. 

At the bottom indicate you want to save the environment for the future, and click Configure. It might take a minute for the configuration to save.

Then, on the right, select the environment, and click Run. You should get your workflow instances.

entry.title: Accelerate Your AI and Innovation Journey with Expert-Guided Services from SAP
entry.content:
At SAP, we are committed to helping our customers innovate and adopt technologies quickly, effectively, and with confidence. As part of this mission, we’re excited to share a series of expert-guided services and enablement opportunities offered through the Foundational success plan designed to help you unlock the power of SAP BTP including AI, SAP Build, and SAP HANA Cloud solutions.

These offerings of Expert Guided Implementation workshops (EGI) from SAP Enterprise Support are tailored to provide hands-on support and guided experiences, helping you get started with the latest innovations while minimizing complexity and accelerating time-to-value.

Whether you're looking to innovate and improve business processes through process automations, harness the power of AI to accelerate innovations, this series has something for everyone.

The following EGI sessions will run throughout the year with quarterly updates to the schedule.

Available Services at a Glance

Topic

Service Name

Description

Vector Engine, Knowledge Graph and Generative AI

SAP HANA Cloud Multiple Model Programming using Vector Engine and Retrieval Augmented Generation

Multi-day service to help customers activate and explore the Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph in SAP HANA Cloud, enabling large language model (LLM) integration and generative AI scenarios. Currently in pilot through the SAP ESAC program.

Joule

Support to Activate Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

2-day service to empower customers on how to fulfil the prerequisites to activate Joule to be used with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (PCE).

Development using Build Code and Joule

SAP Cloud Application Programming Development using SAP Build Code and Joule

Multi-day service to empower customers with the knowledge of CAP Development in SAP HANA Cloud. After the service, customers will know of CAP development and design in SAP HANA Cloud utilizing the SAP Business Application Studio and SAP Build Code with Joule.

SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps

Multi-day service to help customers adopt SAP Build Apps for low-code/no-code development, including hands-on support and best practice guidance.

Process Automation

SAP Build Process Automation

Multi-day guidance designed to help customers get started with SAP Build Process Automation, including hands-on support and best practice guidance.

Administration, Monitoring topics for SAP HANA Cloud

 

Configuration, Administration, Security and Monitoring topics for SAP HANA Cloud

Help customers with SAP HANA Cloud capabilities, key features available and admin tools for database Monitoring.

Modeling in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA Cloud Modeling

Empower customers with the knowledge of Modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.

 What to expect from these services

All services are delivered by SAP experts and follow a structured, guided approach that includes:

  • Overview of the solution capabilities
  • Step-by-step technical guidance
  • Hands-on activities to accelerate learning and adoption
  • Best practices and tips for long-term success

These expert-guided services are ideal for customers looking to accelerate their transformation journey, whether you're exploring AI for the first time, expanding your use of SAP HANA Cloud, or adapting business processes with SAP Build.

How it works

  • Web session, 1-2 hours each morning where SAP expert explains the topic using training materials
  • Duration is from 2 to 5 days depending on the topic
  • Set daily schedule with pre-defined goals for each day
  • Available across different time zones and languages (topic dependent)
  • Afternoon 2-3 hours on the same day where you execute demonstrated steps within your own project, on your own SAP environment
  • During that time, you have direct access to the SAP expert delivering the workshop for guidance and support
  • Registration closes one week before the session date – sign up early!

 If you are interested in participating in these expert-guided services or learning more, simply follow the links above to register for the service.

For customers if you have issues accessing the above links, there may be an authorizations issue. Please note a one-time registration in SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, is required for accessing the EGI service. A detailed step-by step guide to registration can be found here.

A list of the EGI services and all other SAP BTP assets, services and content for SAP Enterprise Support customers are available through the SAP Enterprise Support Value Map program.
